docs.title: Notes
docs.text: This will be where I keep my notes. Eventually, there will be too many notes to sort through. When that time comes, I will figure out some way to organize and navigate through them. For the time being, I will be dumping everything into one spot.

docs.title: BLLLL
docs.text: It is not an exaggeration to say that I live and breathe off of watching and reading BL. If you are anything like me, then you will find some of the resources I have gathered below to be helpful. If you are not, then I would strongly suggest that you give it a shot. For some good starting points, you can try to check out some of my favorite BLs :

docs.title: My Favorite BLs
docs.text:
For anime, I really enjoyed Sasaki and Miyano, Given, and Stranger by the Shore (also check out their respective source manga!). For manga/manhwa, there is One-Room TA, Scene of my Rumspringa (and the spin-off, Dear Gene), and Merry Marbling.

Uyun from One-Room TA (which I especially like).

docs.title: BL YouTube
docs.text:
For some reason (not that I am complaining) there are loads of BL content available on YouTube. They are mostly in the form of short animations (アニメコント) or BL manga dubs (ボイス漫画). Here are some channels I really like :

  • BLサンドいかがですか?
  • GUSH_&.Emo公式【BLボイスコミックチャンネル】
  • アンジェンテ【BLボイスコミックチャンネル】
  • CIELフルールチャンネル【全話無料BLボイスコミック更新中】
  • BLスキップ! オリジナル漫画とアニメ

There are soooo many more, and you can find some of them here.

docs.title: Forum / Sites
docs.text: NSFW Warning. Make sure you are of approriate age before proceeding.

docs.title: Yaoi Sei
docs.text: This site hosts a very extensive collection of doujinshis (both raw and scanlated). Also check out their links section for more resources and other sites.

docs.title: Aarinfantasy
docs.text: is a forum where you can find a variety of BL content (anime, manga, games, etc..) as well as talk about and discuss BL. A (free) account is required to view and participate in the forum.

docs.title: r/BoysLoveAnime
docs.text: Subreddit for BL anime, manga, and manhwa. A good place to keep up with BL news and to get some good recommendations for what to read/watch next.

docs.title: Anki decks for learning Japanese
docs.text: For those who don't know, Anki is a flashcard program which uses spaced repetition to help you learn and memorize stuff. It is especially popular with the Japanese language learning community for memorizing vocabulary and grammar. I have been wanting to study Japanese more seriously so I had to do some digging to figure out which of the many decks (set of flashcards) I should use, and I wanted to share some of what I found in this note.

docs.title: Vocabulary
docs.text: For vocabulary, there seems to be 2 main decks that people use : the JLPT Tango decks, and the Japanese Core decks.

docs.title: JLPT Tango
docs.text: also known as the Ankidrone Essentials. This consists of 5 subdecks based on JLPT level (N5, N4, N3, N2, N1) with sentence examples extracted from the JLPT Tango books (paste はじめての日本語能力試験 into the search bar). You can download / find more info about this deck by clicking here.

docs.title: Japanese Core
docs.text:
This deck is based on the 6,000 most common Japanese words as per iknow.jp. The Core 2k deck contains just the first 2,000 words while the Core 2k/6k deck contains all 6,000. There is also a Core 10k deck which contains an extra 4,000 words (I am not sure where from). You can browse the contents of these decks online at https://core6000.neocities.org.

Warning

As of right now (December 2025), the core6000 website is unreachable, but you can still access a historic copy of it through the internet archive.

docs.title: Other Decks
docs.text: You can find other decks here. Some notable alternatives include the Core 2.3k and Kaishi 1.5k which are (successfull) attempts at refining the original Tango and Core decks.

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text: The Dictionary of Japanese Grammar (DoJG) is basically regarded as THE bible for Japanese grammar. You can find an online version of it here as well as the associated Anki deck here.

docs.title: Making Your Own Deck
docs.text:
After learning some few thousand words, a lot of people suggest moving on to building your own Anki decks. The idea is : whenever you encounter a word you don't know and would like to learn (say while watching an anime), you can extract that word and the surrounding context and turn it into a flashcard; this is known as sentence mining which falls under the more general hood of immersion-based learning.

There are VERY detailed setups / guides on how to do this, some of them also include software and workflows to help automate flashcard creation. Personally, I can't be bothered, but it is fascinating to see some of the effort and research people put into this stuff. I'd like to showcase some of these guides below :

  • animecards
  • donkuri
  • lazyguide
  • jp-mining-note
  • itazuraneko
  • tatsumoto-ren

There are also YT videos on this topic :

  • mikumino
  • Jouzu Juls
  • Livakivi

docs.title: MkDocs : Better Tooltips?
docs.text:
MkDocs already supports tooltips natively. For example :

Markdown
[Try hovering over this]("Hello, I'm a tooltip")

Try hovering over this

docs.title: Make tooltips unclickable
docs.text:
The issue is that the tooltip is clickable and doing so will refresh the page. This is an unwanted function, but we can fix this by adding an appropriate attribute tag with the Attribute Lists extension.

Markdown
[Try hovering over this]("Hello, I'm a tooltip"){: onclick="this.blur(); return false;"}

Try hovering over this

docs.title: Bigger tooltips
docs.text:
While this may be satisfactory, what if I want an even bigger tootlip? What if I want to select and copy something from the tooltip? There is a workaround with MkDocs' instant preview. The idea is that we create a separate markdown file for our tooltips :

tooltips.md
# Tooltips

### Example tooltip

This is an example tooltip. You can now select and copy text from the tooltip. You can even add lists, sample code, etc...

- item 1
- item 2
- item 3

```python
text = "Example Code"
print(test)
```

### Another Tooltip

Lorem Ipsum ...

Whenever we want to bring up this tooltip, we can just add a link to this markdown file at the corresponding header and add the data-preview attribute :

Markdown
[Example Tooltip](../../hidden/tooltips.md#example-tooltip){: data-preview }

[Another Tooltip](../../hidden/tooltips.md#another-tooltip){: data-preview }

Example Tooltip

Another Tooltip

Clicking on the tooltips above brings us to the page associated with tooltips.md but in many cases that is unnecessary. We can remove this functionality by attaching the onclick="this.blur(); return false;" attribute which we used earlier.

Markdown
[Another Tooltip](../../hidden/tooltips.md#another-tooltip){: onclick="this.blur(); return false;" data-preview }

Another Tooltip

docs.title: How I Learn Japanese (Part 1) : Background
docs.text:
This is Part 1 of "How I Learn Japanese" :

  • Part 1 : Background
  • Part 2 : Content

In this multi-part note, I will outline how I learn Japanese and which resources I typically use. To put it shortly, what I do on a pretty much daily basis is watch or read Japanese content, say from anime, YouTube, manga, news, etc.. I am not sure what the effective amount is, but personally, about half of what I consume is Japanese (because I am just that much of a weeb). If I encounter a word or grammar that I am not familiar with, I will try to do some research. Afterwards, I will go back to the sentence (where the word/grammar originated) and check to see if what I have learned makes sense in the original context. Rinse and repeat and that is basically all I have been doing up till this point.

Obivously, what I am describing is not new; it falls under what is known as active immersion. The effectiveness of immersion in comparison to more traditional methods (textbooks, etc..) is a popular (and sometimes toxic) topic of debate in the Japanese language learning community. I do not claim that whatever I am doing will work for you, but at the very least there may be some ideas you can use.

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
I will point out that I did not initially plan to study Japanese, but I enjoyed Japanese YouTubers (I was first introduced through translated clips), and there was eventually a need (which translated clips alone could not satisfy) to watch their content and keep up with the latest info. With the limited amount of Japanese I knew at the time and through sheer stubbornness towards wanting to be part of the fandom, I would painstakingly try to translate and understand videos, tweets, comments, etc.. myself. Without realizing, it became a routine which I'd spend hours each day doing and my Japanese got better just as a byproduct; after all, the main goal was just trying to be part of the fandom.

Tip

I guess what I am trying to say is that motivation is super important for learning new languages, so it might be helpful to think about why you want to be able to understand Japanese in the first place and focus on that as a goal instead, i.e. we want to make it so that learning Japanese becomes a means to an end. It is important that whatever goal you choose should absolutely require knowing Japanese to be achieved; something like "I want to be able to enjoy anime" is not ideal since you could always default to using translations to achieve that goal.

Obviously, this "workflow" will require you to know a bit of Japanese beforehand. At a minimum, you should aim towards already knowing about 30-40% of the vocabulary / grammar you will encounter for this to work without friction; in terms of JLPT levels, this probably amounts to somewhere between N4 and N3. The idea is : you want to be able to get to a point where you can, on your own, be able to at least understand the main plot of whatever it is you are watching or reading so that there is some form of enjoyment to be gained from the process. You can refer to some of the excellent guides I showcased in an earlier note to help you get started to reaching this level.

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text: In the next part, I will be talking about how I source Japanese content to watch / read, as well as some of the tools I use to help streamline this process.

docs.title: How I Learn Japanese (Part 2) : Content
docs.text:
This is Part 2 of "How I Learn Japanese" :

  • Part 1 : Background
  • Part 2 : Content

Naturally, the Japanese content that I read and watch is heavily based on my personal interests, and I would encourage you to do the same. That said, there are some general concepts and ideas which are useful to know.

docs.title: Google IME
docs.text: Learning to type in Japanese will be very helpful since you need to be able to do so in order to search for Japanese content to consume. There are multiple options, but I personally use Google IME to type in Japanese. There are many tutorial videos on YouTube to help get you started, here is one for Google IME specifically.

docs.title: Yomitan
docs.text: is a pop-up dictionary which you can install as a browser extension. You will also need to import a Japanese dictionary (Jitendex is recommended). Once everything is set up, a definition will pop-up simply by hovering over a piece of Japanese text, and then holding the shift key. While yomitan is limited to content displayed in the browser, it is good to know that you can get around this by using tools (I describe some of them below) to load external content (manga, videos, etc..) into the browser.

docs.title: fuseji.net
docs.text:
In Japanese, the 〇 (丸) symbol is used for censorship, for example : エッチ \(\to\) エ〇チ. If you encounter such censorhip, you can use fuseji.net to help fill in the blank. This is also useful in case the audio isn't super clear; just add 〇 to whatever part of a sentence is unclear and fuseji.net will try to guess the full sentence for you. For example, click the link below to check out what fuseji.net thinks the complete sentence should be :

全〇本大〇女〇〇〇対〇〇〇権〇会

Alternatively, you could ask an LLM to do the same task and it will probably perform just as well, if not better. In any case, a correct answer is not guaranteed, so proceed with caution.

docs.title: Subtitle Edit
docs.text:
is a piece of software that allows you to edit and make subtitles with the use of an audio-to-text model. Personally, I use whisper's large-v3-turbo model with a CPP engine, but you should choose what works best for you based on whatever hardware you have available.

This is useful in case you have a piece of media, for which no subtitle is provided, that you want to use for immersion. Obviously the model will make mistakes here and there, so proceed with caution.

docs.title: Surfing the web
docs.text: I am not trying to say that everytime you want to search something up, you should force yourself to do so in Japanese. Instead, there plenty of natural reasons for why it would be a better idea to do so. For instance, I was interested in the art of 落語 (Rakugo) after finishing Descending Stories: Showa Genroku Rakugo Shinju. I wanted to learn more, but the English Wikipedia page was lacking some of the info I was interested in. On the other hand, the Japanese version is far more comprehensive and better suited to my needs. Of course, the caveat is that you would have to decipher all of the Japanese to get what you want, but that is exactly the point.

docs.title: YouTube
docs.text:
I recommend watching videos with hard-coded subs; of which there is no shortage of :

I primarily watch VTubers, アニメコント, and ボイス漫画. The list is quite long so I have decided to include them in a separate note.

docs.title: Anime & Manga
docs.text:
I will not bother explicitly stating how this can be sourced (since it would change every so often anyways due to copyright), but you can refer to wotaku.wiki or any of the other sites listed here for some ideas, both legal and illegal. Once you have obtained your anime / manga, we will need some tools to load this content into the browser so that we can make use of yomitan. For anime, I get JP subs from jimaku.cc and use asbplayer, and for manga I use an OCR tool called mokuro.

Tip : Free raw manga?

Official websites like cmoa.jp, booklive, etc.. frequently provide volumes that are free to read, albeit for a limited time. However, you can bypass this limit by using scripts to download the content and have it stored locally. Other sites like Pixivコミック make the first few + most recent chapters of a manga free to read. Some popular works like Sasaki to Miyano can be found on this site, so it is worth checking out.

Tip : CD Dramas for listening practice

If you are hungry for even more content : ドラマCD (Drama CD) are available for most anime and manga. These drama CDs contain audio only character interactions, so they are good for listening practice. For example, here are some drama CDs for Sasaki to Miyano.

docs.title: Music
docs.text: If you enjoy singing like I do, then singing along to Japanese music is a very fun way to learn. Try glancing through the JP lyrics as you are singing along and before long you will learn to associate the kanji with its sound. You can then take it a step further by trying to translate the lyrics, and then actively recalling the translation while you are singing so that you can associate a particular vocabulary/grammar to its meaning and usage as well.

docs.title: Others
docs.text: There are of course other sources of Japanese content like visual novels, light novels, video games, blogs, social media, etc.. I have no experience using them, but you are free to explore those possibilites.

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text: Now that you have your content, you will be encountering all sorts of unfamiliar vocabulary and grammar. The next step is to turn the unfamiliar into the familiar, and this is where we enter the "research" phase of the learning process, and is what we will be dealing with in the next part.

docs.title: Resources and Guides for Learning Japanese
docs.text: There are sooo many websites dedicated to helping people get started with learning Japanese. The level of effort and detail that has been put into some of these are insane. I've made a list of some of my favorites here :

docs.title: Itazuraneko
docs.text:
also known as the Daily Japanese Thread (DJT) guide. This is probably the most extensive resource / guide out there. Some of the highlights include :

  • a library section where you can find manga, textbooks, light novels, etc...
  • a list of explanations for differences in nuance between words/phrases with similar meanings.
  • a master list of Japanese grammar compiled from 5 different sources.

and so much more, check it out yourself. Below are some mirrors for this website in case the main link no longer works :

  • https://gohoneko.neocities.org/
  • https://kenrick95.github.io/itazuraneko/index.html
  • https://djtguide.neocities.org/

docs.title: Tatsumoto Ren
docs.text: A guide for learning Japanese based on the All Japanese All The Time (AJATT) method. Their list of resources is very extensive and useful.

docs.title: TheMoeWay
docs.text: A guide for learning Japanese with a focus on using anime, manga, VNs, etc.. Their list of resources is also very extensive and useful.

docs.title: Wotaku
docs.text: Mainly a resource aggregator for otakus, but also has a great section for Japanese language learning.

docs.title: Japanese with Anime
docs.text:
A guide which uses sentence examples from anime and manga to explain grammar concepts and vocabulary. The vocabulary you can learn from this website is heavily geared toward otaku culture. For example, there are explanations for words like : isekai (異世界), NEET (ニート), etc...

Beyond that, the website also hosts pages on more general topics in otaku culture, like a page explaining what is meant by an OVA and how it compares to ONAs and OADs. There are also pages which explain common anime tropes like the tehepero pose or the anime fang. Pages which explain internet slang terms like wwww, and many more...

docs.title: Kuzuri
docs.text: This website lists commonly misused Japanese words and phrases and explains how to avoid those mistakes.

docs.title: Sakubi, Imabi, Yokubi
docs.text:
All three of these are excellent Japanese grammar references. Although Imabi is very well written and extensive, many people regard it as being too terse and academic. As a response, Sakubi was created as a more accessible alternative. Later on, some people decided to revise and restructure Sakubi, resulting in what is now known as Yokubi. Other noteworthy grammar references include Tofugu and Bunpro.

Warning

As of December 2025, Yokubi is still in development and not fully complete.

docs.title: Cure Dolly
docs.text: was a VTuber who came up with quite a novel model to explain Japanese sentence structure. She has a playlist with 93 lessons teaching Japanese from scratch with this model. If you are not a video type of person, you can also refer to the notes that have been made based on her videos. Unfortunately, Cure Dolly passed away back in 2021 despite there being so much more to teach.

docs.title: Konomu
docs.text: How does one choose between は and が? This is a notoriously difficult question to answer, so much so that entire books have been written on this topic. This website is a very long guide which goes over all the nuances in dealing with this question.

docs.title: More...
docs.text:
For more cool websites and resources, check out these github repos :

  • https://github.com/GaijinRyman/LearningJapaneseResources
  • https://github.com/yudataguy/Awesome-Japanese
  • https://github.com/donkuri/japanese-resources

docs.title: Japanese YouTubers I Watch
docs.text: Despite only understanding like half of what's going on, one of the reasons I continue to watch Japanese YouTube is to improve my Japanese. For that reason, I tend to watch channels that provide JP subtitles to help with the learning process. Hopefully the day will come where I can finally enjoy a video without having to open a dictionary every minute, but for now I have to keep practising. Below are some of the channels I particularly enjoy watching :

docs.title: VTubers
docs.text:
I usually watch VTubers from nijisanji. In particular, stuff from their main channel, ChroNoiR, ROF-MAO, and seitokai.

Besides nijisanji, I also watch :

  • mafumafu (his 立ち絵動画 and 変な動画 playlists in particular)
  • soraru
  • amatsuki
  • ado
  • sutopuri
  • atatakakunaru (takao shinji in particular)
  • kokubibi

I also watch clips from these VTubers. They are much shorter compared to videos/streams, and are edited to include subs. Sometimes the clips include animations and drawings which make them more fun to watch. Below are some clip channels I often frequent :

  • 朝と海
  • kage
  • くじくじ
  • そらまふ大好きチャネル
  • yeejya
  • ねむねむにゃんこ | nemu-nemu-nyanko

Tip

You can find more clips of VTubers (or anyone else really) by using 「VTuber」+ 切り抜き / 文字起こし / 手書き as a search term on YouTube.

docs.title: アニメコント
docs.text:
The コント in アニメコント comes from the french word conte which translates to "tale" (as in story, fable, etc..) in English. アニメコント is therefore "animated tales", and it is a popular genre of video in Japan. The western equivalent to アニメコント would probably be something like "animated skits" (think videos/shorts by Plan3, etc..) which is also very popular.

Here are some of the ones I regularly watch :

  • 私立パラの丸高校
  • マリマリマリー
  • くつずれデイズ
  • たすくこま
  • オムオムアニメ【コント】
  • ピュティフィ
  • いくとん
  • ふじこふじこ

These ones are more long-form and story (as opposed to gag) oriented, but also very good :

  • テイコウペンギン
  • 混血のカレコレ
  • ハンドレッドノート / HUNDRED NOTE【公式】
  • 【アニメ】あたしンち公式チャンネル

docs.title: ボイス漫画
docs.text:
As the name suggests, ボイス漫画 (also known as ボイスコミック) are just manga dubs. Often, they are made available by the publishers themselves for promotional purposes. For example, JUMP! and Kadokawa will sometimes post ボイス漫画 on their channels. Here are some publishers I have found and their respective channels, but there's bound to be loads more :

  • ジャンプチャンネル
  • KADOKAWAオフィシャルチャンネル
  • キトラ【KADOKAWAキトラ公式ボイストゥーン】
  • コミックエッセイ劇場【公式】
  • 双葉社公式コミックチャンネル
  • エースこみっくチャンネル
  • コミックブリーゼチャンネル【公式】
  • BKレーベル公式【ラノベボイスコミックチャンネル】
  • 【公式】PASH! コミックス・ブックス・文庫
  • ゼロサムYouTubeチャンネル
  • コミックジーンチャンネル

ボイス漫画 doesn't necessarily have to be based on an actual published title. If someone wants to make content or tell a story with that style then they are free to do so, and this is exactly what FermiLab (also check out here and here) did to create educational videos.

docs.title: BL
docs.text: Yes, I watch BL. If it has not been clear, I am a 腐男子 (fudanshi). For some reason (not that I am complaining) there are loads of BL content on YouTube, and I feel that it is best if I just shove all of it into a separate note.

docs.title: Misc
docs.text:
This is just a place for YouTube content I watch that don't really fit into the previous categories :

  • Table top role playing games (TRPGs), in particular Call of Cthulu, is popular in Japan and is a source of a lot of fun content (check out あそびいと and まにむ).

docs.title: Resources for Otakus
docs.text:
Below are some great aggregators which you can use to fulfill all of your otaku needs. I mainly use them to keep track of the latest methods to watch anime or read manga. I really like Wotaku in particular.

  • Wotaku
  • The Index
  • The Wiki
  • EverythingMoe
